content.html:
MediaWiki extensions have two basic options for releasing: one (called rel) is to have a separate branch for each major[^1] version of core; the other (called master) is to only have one branch and to make it compatible with as many versions of core that the maintainer wants (hopefully all current versions). Extensions also have a version number of their own, and for years it‚Äôs confused me. I think that it doesn‚Äôt make sense to have a version number with a rel compatibility policy. It does make sense for master (and in that case, the automatically-created REL1_* branches should be deleted).

[^1]: note that MediaWiki doesn‚Äôt use Semantic Versioning, so it‚Äôs not the first number; that‚Äôs always 1.
content.value:
MediaWiki extensions have two basic options for releasing: one (called rel) is to have a separate branch for each major[^1] version of core; the other (called master) is to only have one branch and to make it compatible with as many versions of core that the maintainer wants (hopefully all current versions). Extensions also have a version number of their own, and for years it‚Äôs confused me. I think that it doesn‚Äôt make sense to have a version number with a rel compatibility policy. It does make sense for master (and in that case, the automatically-created REL1_* branches should be deleted).
[^1]: note that MediaWiki doesn‚Äôt use Semantic Versioning, so it‚Äôs not the first number; that‚Äôs always 1.

content.html: Submissions are closed now. I guess it was a ‚Äúbe prepared to start blogging in January‚Äù sort of thing.
content.value: Submissions are closed now. I guess it was a ‚Äúbe prepared to start blogging in January‚Äù sort of thing.

content.html:
Bring Back Blogging sounds like a good idea.

For the month of January, we‚Äôll make a pact to post a few times to get into the habit, and create a directory of all the creators who participate.

They obviously know some bloggers‚Äô favourite hobby:

isn‚Äôt redesigning your blog template for the tenth time this month so much more stimulating than doom scrolling?

Maybe I should start blogging again.
content.value:

content.html: There does seem to be a massive pull (a feeling of it being a good idea) to post to places on the internet where one can get that feeling of being appreciated when someone clicks ‚Äòlike‚Äô. Those places are also where not getting likes makes you feel crap. At the moment, I prefer being here in the ignored bit where I have zero idea of who looks at what, and it‚Äôs just a sort of public jotting down of random words and pictures. Much more relaxing. Also means I can stuff around with building the software, which of course is probably the main point for me!

Those places are also where not getting likes makes you feel crap. At the moment, I prefer being here in the ignored bit where I have zero idea of who looks at what, and it‚Äôs just a sort of public jotting down of random words and pictures. Much more relaxing. Also means I can stuff around with building the software, which of course is probably the main point for me!

content.html: It‚Äôs strangely cool for January, this Sunday morning. My brain isn‚Äôt really awake yet. Not that too much whiskey was tasted yesterday; just the right amount.

content.html: Well, it‚Äôs half nine on a Friday night, so I might as well keep scanning I think. I‚Äôm getting a few more things uploaded to Commons, and trying not to get too drawn into reading about the 1930s aviation stuff.

content.html:
I‚Äôm trying to add a plain-text export option to Twyne (of varying sorts: LaTeX and Markdown to start with). I couldn‚Äôt figure out why my code wasn‚Äôt working.

Turns out there is no mime type called text/pain.

content.html:
I really do like Thunderbird. It‚Äôs such a great email client, and having actual local software feels like such a rare thing these days. I think my favourite features are

  1. local folders, so I can store email actually where I want (and sync it into Nextcloud‚Ä¶ but that‚Äôs another story); and
  2. one-button automatic annual archiving (select emails, hit a, and they‚Äôre moved to year-named folders on my local disk).

The one thing I don‚Äôt like at the moment is that I can‚Äôt easily switch to Maildir (from Mbox) as the storage format. I‚Äôve only ever, in 22 years of paying attention to this sort of thing, had a problem. But that did annoy me, that one time that I got a corrupted email folder! (Actually, I haven‚Äôt really looked at the state of Thunderbird‚Äôs Maildir support recently, so I‚Äôm probably way out of date on this.)
content.value:

local folders, so I can store email actually where I want (and sync it into Nextcloud‚Ä¶ but that‚Äôs another story); and
one-button automatic annual archiving (select emails, hit a, and they‚Äôre moved to year-named folders on my local disk).

The one thing I don‚Äôt like at the moment is that I can‚Äôt easily switch to Maildir (from Mbox) as the storage format. I‚Äôve only ever, in 22 years of paying attention to this sort of thing, had a problem. But that did annoy me, that one time that I got a corrupted email folder! (Actually, I haven‚Äôt really looked at the state of Thunderbird‚Äôs Maildir support recently, so I‚Äôm probably way out of date on this.)

name: Sam Wilson
note:
I‚Äôm a programmer from Fremantle, Western Australia. I work for the Wikimedia Foundation and spend my spare time working on wikis, family history, and OpenStreetMap. I try to find time for some furniture-making.
Contact me by email, or on the fediverse/Mastodon as @samwilson@wikis.world, or on Matrix as @samwilson:matrix.org.
